section.title: XMetaL
section.p:
Documents handled by Cassis TI are authored in
XMetaL
XMetaL, a standards-compliant XML editor from JustSystems. Of course, any XML-compliant editor will do (actually, any text editor that handles the UTF-8 UTF-8 character encoding format will do), but support and Cassis-specific functionality is only provided for XMetaL.
This chapter is about the various tasks required to write a manual using XMetaL.

list.p: There are several ways to start the Cassis TI authoring environment for XMetaL XMetaL:

list-item.p: Log in to the Cassis TI repository from XMetaL's Resource Manager and the Cassis TI tab. If Resource Manager is not visible, open it by selecting View->Resource Manager.

note.p: This establishes the connection between the editor and the repository. It does not in itself open or create any documents, however. Also, offline editing of Cassis TI documents is available for any resource checked out and available on the local machine. These documents need to be opened separately, using XMetaL's Open dialog or some other Windows-compliant method.

list-item.p: Open an XML document written using a Cassis-compliant DTD DTD.
Create a new document by choosing File->New and the tab that includes the Cassis-compliant document types.

Create a new document by choosing File->New and, from the tab General, Blank XML Document. Then choose a Cassis-compliant rules file (rlx file)
rules file (a
DTD, compiled for XMetaL DTD compiled for XMetaL XMetaL, with a .rlx suffix) from the Browse dialog box that appears, and finally a top (root) element for the document.

note.p: The Cassis-specific customisations will also load if XMetaL XMetaL starts with a previously opened Cassis-compliant XML document.

step-list.p: To creating a new XML document create a new XML document for use in Cassis, do the following:

step.p: Choose File->New and the Cassis TI tab containing the Cassis-specific templates.
Choose the appropriate document type template and click OK.

note.p:
If the desired document type is not included in the templates, instead choose File->New and, from the General tab, Blank XML Document. Then choose a Cassis-compliant rules file (rlx file)
rules file (a
DTD, compiled for XMetaL DTD compiled for XMetaL XMetaL, with a .rlx suffix) from the Browse dialog box that appears, and finally a top (root) element for the document.

step.p: Write the desired contents, and save the document on your local hard drive.
Register the document in Cassis by uploading it into the repository from the web interface. For information how to do this, see .

note.p: Subsequent check-outs and check-ins can be performed from XMetaL.

section.p:
Documents are normally checked in or out from Cassis using the Repository (tab)

section.title: Checking Out Documents

step-list.p: To checking out (XMetaL) check out a document, do the following:

step.p:
Open the Repository (tab)
Repository tab in XMetaL's Resource Manager.
Maneuver to the desired repository folder and right-click the desired XML document.

note.p: A double-click will open the document for viewing in XMetaL XMetaL, without checking out the document from the database.

step.p: Select Check Out. The document is checked out and opened in XMetaL XMetaL.

section.p: While checked out, the document can not be checked out or edited by anyone else. A red marker (see ) indicates that the document is checked out by the user; a yellow marker on the document icon (see ) indicates that someone else has checked out the document.

note.p: Hovering the mouse pointer on the icon on a document checked out by another user will show that person's username.

step-list.p: To checking in (XMetaL) check in a document, do the following:

step.p:
Open the Repository (tab)
Repository tab in XMetaL's Resource Manager.
Maneuver to the desired Cassis repository folder and right-click the desired XML document.
Select Check In or Check In and Close.

note.p: To keep the checked-in document open in XMetaL XMetaL, select Check In. The document can no longer be edited but remains open.

step.p: The Cassis MetaData window opens.
Enter any relevant metadata applicable to the new version. Click OK to save the changes to the metadata and close the dialog, or Cancel to close the dialog without saving changes.

note.p: Check the Do not show this dialog on checkin checkbox to avoid opening the dialog when checking in documents.

section.title: Viewing and Editing Metadata
section.p: The metadata of any TI resource can be viewed from within XMetaL. If the resource is checked in, its metadata can also be edited.

step-list.p: Use the following steps to view or edit metadata for a resource:

step.p: Right-click the resource in any Cassis TI tab in Resource Manager. Choose View/Edit Metadata.
The Cassis MetaData dialog opens. If the resource is checked out, the metadata fields are greyed out and read-only.
Inspect or edit the resource's metadata. Click OK to save the changes and close the window, or click Cancel to close the window without saving any changes.

section.title: Workspace
section.p: The Workspace (tab)Workspace tab is a convenient way to handle any currently open or checked out documents. Any operation that can be done from other Cassis TI tabs in Resource Manager can also be carried out from the Workspace tab.
The Workspace tab contains a link to the current Cassis TI repository. Clicking the link opens the Cassis TI web interface in a browser window.

figure.caption: The Log Out Button and the Cassis TI Web Link

section.p: If necessary, it is possible to log out from the repository by clicking the Log Out button. The log out action returns the user to the Cassis TI login tab (see ).

section.title: Inserting Content from Other XML Documents
section.p: This section outlines the steps needed to create an insert link, that is, to include content from another document in the document at hand.

admonishment.p:
The element type
link targets, allowed target element type pointed at in the target document inset (link type)
must be an element type that is allowed where the inset link is created! If the target element type is not allowed in the link context, the publishing process will break!

Make sure that the target document does not contain a reference to the document at hand, either directly or by a document referenced in the target document! Such a circular reference circular link will break the publishing process!

note.p: It is possible to include content from the current document. Why one would want to do so remains a mystery to the author of this user guide, however.

section.title: Creating and Editing Tables
section.p:
Tables can easily be inserted into a document using standard functionality in XMetaL, table editing
XMetaL XMetaL. However, do not create a table by inserting a table element from the Element List (pane)
Element List pane, as the table will not be formatted properly in the XMetaL editor window. Instead, choose Table->Insert Table from the menu bar.

note.p: See the XMetaL Online Help for more information on how to create tables.

section.p:
Colspec Editor (dialog box) There are things XMetaL's standard table editing functionality does not handle, however, most importantly the ability to specify column widths. To this end, the Cassis TI authoring environment provides the Colspec Editor (dialog box)
Colspec Editor dialog box (see ).

step-list.p: To edit the column widths of a table, do the following:

step.p: Place the cursor within the table start tag.

Click the Edit Colspecs (button)
Edit Colspecs button in the Cassis toolbar, or choose Ctrl+Alt+T. The Colspec Editor (dialog box)
Colspec Editor dialog box opens.

Choose the column number of the desired column from the Column Number (drop-down list)
Column Number drop-down list. The current column width is displayed in the Column Width (edit box)
Column Width edit box.

Edit the value in the Column Width (edit box)
Column Width edit box.

note.p: Only relative values are allowed, either using only a numeric value or a numeric value followed by an asterisk. A unit such as inches will be ignored.

step.p: Repeat the last step with every column.
Click OK. The window closes, and the table is reformatted accordingly.

section.title: Applying Applicabilities
section.p: The concept of applicabilities is central to Cassis TI and the reuse of previously written material in new contexts. Therefore we strongly urge the reader to familiarise herself with the basic principles behind applicabilities before following the steps in this section. These principles are explained in detail in .

The applics values are easily edited in the Cassis TI authoring interface, using the Set Applics (dialog box)
Set Applics dialog box.

note.p:
The Set Applics (dialog box)
Set Applics dialog box is customised for each Cassis TI installation so its actual appearance will vary.

step-list.p: To set applicabilities on an element, do the following:

step.p: Place the cursor inside the start tag of the desired element.

Click Apply Applics (button)
Apply Applics on the
Cassis Toolbar
Cassis Toolbar. The Set Applics dialog box opens.

If the current element is a child or descendant of the element requiring applicabilities, click the Move Up button. The nearest ancestor element that allows applicabilities is chosen instead. Repeat this to move further up in the structure.

note.p: If trying to move above the root element of the document, a warning is displayed.

step.p:
Choose the applic condition(s). These will be displayed in the Applic Value (list box)
Applic Value list box, along with any previously selected applics.

note.p: Applic values or combinations cannot be inserted more than once. Double occurrences are discarded.

step.p:
To delete an existing applic value, select it in the Applic Value (list box)
Applic Value list box and click Delete marked.

When finished, click OK. The Set Applics (dialog box)
Set Applics dialog box closes, and new applic values are added to the applic (attribute)
applic attribute for the element.
